reviewText: I love the adventure and the history of this item.This show lets you be part of the adventure and shows you that history can be exciting.If you like the Indiana Jones shows or Lora Croft you will love these shows.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Thanks to the hit that is Lara Croft we were able to get this series for three entertaining seasons, and while the historical facts were humorous to downright ridiculous the series was still enjoyable to watch and now own.  The series gave you the female archeological teacher thinking lost historical treasures with her timid to later on more reliable and confident assistant as they traveled the globe going against tomb raiders and nefarious villains.  The shows a guilty pleasure but one expected around this time as we had Hercules/Xena/DS9/Babylon 5 but still overall the series gave us what we wanted and that was to be entertained at the end.  The video and audio are sharp and clear with the video having a little better looking clarity then the first season.  So for those of us who first saw the show when it air or for people looking for a action adventure series at a reasonable price here's a decent set to add to your home library...
summary: Enjoyable Action Adventure Show But One Where You Have To Lower Your Intelligence On Historical Facts
Title: N/A

reviewText: Lots of times when you go back and watch a show again for the first time in a long while you wonder what you were thinking "back then"! That's not the case with Relic Hunter! Sure there are some moments where you need to suspend your disbelief, but if you are looking for a fun show, with some humor and a kick ass female lead, you won't do better than Relic Hunter. All three seasons are worth your time. They are reasonably priced for 22 episodes, sadly there are no bonus features. Many have called it part Tomb Raider and part Indiana Jones. I would somewhat agree with that, but I find this more enjoyable than Tomb Raider.
summary: Just as good as I remember!
Title: N/A

reviewText: After viewing the first episode of 'RELIC HUNTER'S' second season, you know you have experienced a big change.  Gone are the HA-HA-HA-HEE-HEE-HEE antics which novacained the first season, the characters and storylines are much more serious and the production values have increased to the point of more exotic locales such as Paris, Hungary, to name but a few.  There is a new Producer, Jonathan Hackett and Gerard Groce comes on board as executive Producer.  There is also a new story Editor Charles Heit who collected some solid scripts for the season.  The direction is conducted masterfully by a trio of talents: Paulo Barzmann who directed some of 'HIGHLANDER's best episodes, Ian Thoynton and John Bell.  But the acting by Tia Carrere as Sydney Fox and Christian Anholt as Nigel Bailey has improved immensely as they embrace their roles with relish and bring a reality to their performances which no others could have done.  However, my memory failed me as I was a bit premature in my review of the first season about Lindy Booth's character of Claudia leaving the series.  She appears front and center in at least three of the seasons best episodes and abets our heroes with great aplomb. We also see backgrounds on our main characters as Nigel's brother joins the action in one excursion and Sydney is given a gift in the first episode in the form of a Relic Hunter utility belt formed like a pocket knife which folds out into a mini crossbow which gets our heroes out of deadly scrapes.  You will also see guest stars such as Fred Dryer playing Sydney's father , a young Steven Bauer and Nigel Bennett who graced the three seasons of 'FOREVER KNIGHT" as the vampire you loved to hate, Lucien Lacroix.  But the mastery of the seasons technicians is amazing as each episode resembles a mini movie in its 38 minute running time making it a jewel that Sydney would be proud of finding.  Alliance Films releases all 22 episodes full screen in crisp transfers with Dolby Digital sound but beware, like the first season package, the discs come out of their slots very easily tending to scratch and their are no extras.  For lovers of action, this is a treasure trove and makes it all the tragedy that they never used Tia Carrere in more productions to show her talent of martial arts and drama. This second season is as fresh today as it was 11 years ago,  and now , on to Season Three which I never saw in complete form and really looking forward to.
summary: Second Verse Same As The First But With Grit
